title: Icon buttons
description: Icon buttons help people take supplementary actions with a single tap.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use icon buttons when a compact button is required, such as in a toolbar or image list. There are two types of icon buttons: standard and contained.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Standard icon button
2. Contained icon button (including filled, filled tonal, and outlined styles)
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of standard and contained icon buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – Toggle buttonAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Icon buttons can take the form of a wide range of system icons
  • Ensure the meaning of the icon is unambiguous
  • On hover, include a tooltip that describes the button’s action, rather than the name of the icon itself
  • Use the outline-style icons to indicate an unselected state and a filled style to indicate selection
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color.
  • Name and types: Icon buttons were previously known as toggle buttons. They now have two official types: standard and contained.

contentChunks.footer: Icon buttons can have a container or not.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of icon buttons with and without containers

contentChunks.htmlValue:

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Usage
Anatomy
Placement
Behavior

contentChunks.altText: 3 example cards with headlines and body text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Use icon buttons to display actions in a compact layout. Icon buttons can represent opening actions such as opening an overflow menu or search, or represent binary actions that can be toggled on and off, such as favorite or bookmark.

Icon buttons can be grouped together or they can stand alone.

contentChunks.footer: Icon buttons can be used within other components, such as a bottom app bar.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with several icon buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are two types of icon buttons:

  1. Standard icon button
  2. Contained icon button

contentChunks.footer: Both standard icon buttons (1) and contained icon buttons (2) can be toggled – displaying a selected or unselected state.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of standard and contained icon buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Use a contained icon button when the component requires more visual separation from the background.

Both types of icon buttons share the same functionality, so which one you use can depend on style alone.

contentChunks.footer: Use contained icon buttons in cases that require more visual separation or hierarchy.
contentChunks.altText: Card component with contained icon button over image

contentChunks.footer: Avoid using contained icon butttons alongside filled or outlined buttons as it doesn’t create enough hierachy in actions.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of restaurant results with filled icon buttons next to filled buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contained icon buttons can have one of three styles:

  • Filled
  • Filled tonal
  • Outlined


Filled icon buttons have higher visual impact and are best for high emphasis actions.

contentChunks.footer: Use filled icon buttons for high emphasis actions, such as turning off a microphone or camera.
contentChunks.altText: Example of two icon buttons set on bottom screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Filled tonal icon buttons are a middle ground between filled and outlined icon buttons. They’re useful in contexts where the button requires slightly more emphasis than an outline would give, such as a secondary action paired with a high emphasis action.

contentChunks.footer: Use a toggle icon button for actions like Raise hand in a video meeting. When selected, its visual emphasis is greater than the medium-emphasis outlined button for the Overflow menu, but less than the high-emphasis filled button for End call.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side examples of three different icon buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outlined icon buttons are medium-emphasis buttons. They’re useful when an icon button needs more emphasis than a standard icon button but less than a filled or filled tonal icon button.

contentChunks.footer: Use outlined icon buttons in cases that require a more emphasis than a standard icon button, but less than a filled or tonal icon button. Here, outlined icon buttons indicate that more content is available.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Icon
2. Container (visible in contained icon buttons only)
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of standard and filled icon buttons indicating the 2 parts of its anatomy

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon

Icons visually communicate the button’s action. Their meaning should be clear and unambiguous.

contentChunks.footer: Ensure that the meaning of the icon is clear, such as a heart indicating “Add to favorites.”
contentChunks.altText: UI of restaurants list with heart icon to add to favorites

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

The container holds the icon and is visible for contained icon buttons only. 

It provides increased contrast and hierarchy in places that need more visual separation from the background or other elements.

contentChunks.footer: The container of contained icon buttons provides visual separation from the image background.
contentChunks.altText: Video call UI with filled icon button controls on video image

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement
Icon buttons are best suited for areas where a compact layout is needed, such as a toolbar.

contentChunks.footer: In denser UIs, icon buttons allow for many actions in a compact layout.
contentChunks.altText: Spreadsheet UI with many icon buttons in toolbar

contentChunks.htmlValue: Icon buttons are commonly found within top app bars and cards.

contentChunks.footer: Top app bars often contain icon buttons.
contentChunks.altText: Restaurant listing UI with icon buttons in top app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Hover

On hover, the icon button displays a tooltip describing its action, rather than the name of the icon itself.

contentChunks.footer: The tooltip label text should be clear and concise.
contentChunks.altText: Cursor hovering over heart icon button with tooltop that reads add to favorites

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Selection

Toggle icon buttons allow a single choice to be selected or deselected, such as adding or removing something from favorites.

contentChunks.footer: Do use toggle icon buttons when the icon can be selected. For example, here a contained icon button can be toggled to star a song.
contentChunks.altText: Card component with toggle icon button over image to star a song

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use toggle icon buttons for actions that don’t have a selected state, such as an icon button for an overflow menu.
contentChunks.altText: Overflow menu icon button incorrectly toggled on while menu is open

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Indicating selection

Use outline-style icons to indicate an unselected state and a filled style to indicate a selected state.

contentChunks.footer: When making a selection, such as bookmarking or saving a video, the icon shifts from outlined (unselected) to filled (selected).
contentChunks.altText: Card components with bookmarking icon button shifting to filled icon button when toggled on

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to: 

  • Understand meaning of the icon
  • Navigate to and activate an icon button with assistive technology
  • When applicable, a tooltip is available to help describe the icon button's purpose
Interaction & style
Ensure the icon passes a minimum of 3:1 contrast ratio.

contentChunks.footer: Icon button does pass the 3:1 contrast ratio.
Avoid icon buttons that fail the 3:1 contrast ratio.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

Keys
Actions
TabFocus lands on (non-disabled) icon button
Space / EnterActivates the (non-disabled) icon button
Labeling elements
The accessibility labels for icon buttons describe the action that the button is executing, such as Favorite, Bookmark, or Send message.

contentChunks.footer: The label for icon describes the action, such as Favorite for the heart icon.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Layout and density

Group of similar components can be nested together inside a component or they can stand alone.

The target size of each icon button should always be at least 48dp, even when nested together.

contentChunks.footer: Icon buttons can be used within other components, such as a bottom app bar.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Hover
On hover, the icon button may display a tooltip describing its action, rather than the name of the icon itself.

contentChunks.footer: The tooltip label text should be clear and concise.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources
• Information on clustering
